docs.lead_paragraph: Could Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s antismoking crusade have already saved hundreds of lives? It has, city health officials said yesterday.

headline.main: Mayor’s Curb on Smoking Is Credited With Saving Lives

docs.lead_paragraph: A Komodo dragon called Flora has surprised her keepers at Chester Zoo in northern England by laying viable eggs that are due to hatch next month. She has been bred in captivity and has never been kept with a male, British scientists say in the journal Nature. Kevin Buley, a reptile expert at the zoo and a co-author of the paper, said in a statement on Nature’s Web site, “We were blown away when we realized what she’d done.” Some other reptile species reproduce asexually in a process known as parthenogenesis. But Flora’s conception, and that of another Komodo, Sungai, who gave birth to four dragon hatchlings at the London Zoo in April through self-fertilization, are the first documented in a Komodo dragon, the world’s largest lizard. Scientists are unsure whether female Komodos have always had this latent ability to reproduce, or if this is a new evolutionary development. Concerns about dwindling Komodo populations might be allayed by Flora and Sungai’s self-induced motherhood. “If female dragons can on occasion help out by virgin births, more power to them,” said Trooper Walsh, a United States-based Komodo dragon expert.

headline.main: Britain: Pregnant Dragon Is a Father-to-be
headline.print_headline: Britain: Pregnant Dragon Is a Father-to-be

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER 10 seasons as Monica Geller, the nerdy neatnik on the hit series ''Friends,'' Courteney Cox could have walked into the offices of any television network in Hollywood and had executives open their wallets for the right to feature her in a new series. So why, for ''Dirt,'' her first television project in nearly three years, did Ms. Cox choose the FX cable channel? It attracts fewer than one million households in prime time each night, according to Nielsen Media Research, one-quarter the number who still tune in to nightly reruns of ''Friends.''

headline.main: No Longer a Friend, Ready to Get Dirty

docs.abstract: Actress Courtney Cox will star in new FX series Dirt, about tabloid journalism; Cox and her husband David Arquette are executive producers of show; Cox's own problems with paparazzi and issue of privacy vs public desire to know about celebrities discussed; photos (M)
